questions.text: Which orbital wall is most protective to eye from blunt trauma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Lateral wall is strongest wall of the orbit

questions.text: Most common collagen in vitreous
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
In vitreous, shielding of type II collagen (most common) is by type IX collagen.

questions.text: A patient was noted to have such finding. The pathology is related to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous
Primary vitreous is hyaloid vessel, and anterior remnant of hyaloid artery is known as
Mittendorf spots and posterior remnant of hyaloid artery is known as Bergmeister’s papilla.

questions.text: The cells not involved in visual pathway are
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The end organ is the neural epithelium of the rods and cones. The first conducting nerve cell or neurone of the bipolar cell of the inner nuclear layer of the retina. The neurones of the ganglion cells in the retina, the processes of which pass into the nerve fibre layer and along the optic nerve to the lateral geniculate body .

questions.text: Binocular vision includes all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Binocular vision has been graded into three levels— simultaneous macular perception, fusion and stereopsis. An object has to be simultaneously imaged by the foveae of the two eyes and the images perceived and fused by the brain, with the horizontal disparity leading to the perception of

choices.text: It is located outside the muscle cone
Post ganglion fibres pass through nerve to the inferior oblique muscle

questions.text: Which of the following is false the structure marked?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The ciliary ganglion is located within the muscle cone, just behind the globe. Ciliary ganglion serves as a conduit for other nerve fibres, only the parasympathetic fibres synapse there.
Third (preganglionic motor) connects the Edinger–Westphal nucleus to the ciliary ganglion. The parasympathetic fibres pass through the oculomotor nerve, enter its inferior division and reach the ciliary ganglion via the nerve to the inferior oblique muscle.

questions.text: Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lesion of the ciliary ganglion: abolition of the light reflex with retention of the near reflex, sometimes with tonic contraction (Adie pupil).
Here there is right side Adie pupil.

questions.text: The symptom can be seen in all of the following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Coloured haloes are seen in acute congestive glaucoma, corneal edema, early cataract and in mucopurulent conjunctivitis.

choices.text: Better to check visual acuity in Amblyopia
Based on minimal angle of resolution

questions.text: True for the given chart is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

ETDRS (Early treatment of diabetic retinopathy chart)
Single letter vision is better than if the letters are presented in a row as is the norm in visual acuity charts. This is known as crowding phenomenon, seen in amblyopias. Snellen overestimate vision of amblyopia.

questions.text: All are charts for contrast sensitivity except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Farnsworth Munsell is for colour sense

choices.text: Immature senile cataract, phacoemulsification with IOL

questions.text: 75 years old patient was seen on slit lamp and following was observed. Which is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Blunt trauma has rosette cataract

questions.text: Identify the cataract?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Morgagnian hypermature cataract: cortex dissolves, nucleus settles below  in lens

questions.text: A 55 year old diabetic male developed gradual painless loss of vision. He was diagnosed to have cataract. Which of the following type will he have?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Senile cataract tends to develop at an earlier age and more rapidly than usual in diabetic subjects. The lenses of an adult diabetic are said to be in the same condition as a nondiabetic who is 15 years older. 

True diabetic cataract (snowflake) is a rare condition occurring typically in young people in whom the diabetes is so acute as to disturb grossly the water balance of the body.

questions.text: The following investigations are done before cataract surgery except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pachymetry measures corneal thickness which is not necessary before cataract surgery.
Specular microscopy evaluates endothelium of cornea (endothelial decompensation can occur after complicated surgery)

questions.text: Which surgery is being performed here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Lens aspiration and intraocular lens implantation is being done during cataract surgery.

questions.text: Preferred formula for IOL calculation in a patient with post LASIK would be
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Adjustments in the formula are required and several have been suggested such as Holladay (which is recommended for long eyeballs), Hoffer for short eyeballs.

choices.text: It will cause glare at night
Photocoagulative laser is used for management

questions.text: True for the following complication after cataract surgery are all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Higher rates of Posterior Capsular Opacification are reported in younger patients, with PMMA lenses and hydrophilic acrylic lenses. Lower rates are seen with older patients, and those with hydrophobic acrylic lenses and new-generation silicon lenses with square posterior edges.
Photodisruptive laser (ND YAG 1064 nm) is used for laser capsulotomy.

questions.text: After cataract the surgeron did a test and resutured the wound. Which test was done?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Siedel test: fluoroscein dye is used to stain ocular surface. If aqueous is leaking, dye gets diluted indication Siedel test positive

questions.text: The late phase of fluorescein angiography in a patient who complained of decreased vision few months after uncomplicated cataract surgery with appearance as in figure will be most likely having
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The late phase of fluorescein angiography showing petalloid hyperfluorescence in the macular region typical of cystoid macular oedema

questions.text: Which has segments of photoreceptors
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

a- ganglion layer
b- outer plexiform
c- outer nuclear layer
d- photoreceptor

questions.text: A 45 year old lady presented with diminution of vision since 1 month. Vision was 6/24 both eyes. On fundus examination, there were intra retinal hemorrhages in 2 quadrants with venous beading in 2 quadrants. Likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B).

Very Mild NPDR – microaneurysms
Mild to Mod NPDR - + few hemorrages
Severe NPDR – 4 : 2 : 1 rule,  4 quadrant hemorrages, 2 quadrant venous beading, 1 quadrant IRMA.
                       If 1 of these - severe NPDR
                       If 2 or more of these – very severe NPDR

questions.text: The pathology lies in.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Angiod streaks  are due to changes in the elastic tissue of Bruch’s membrane.

questions.text: All can be seen in in a patient with axial length of 28 mm except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

High (Pathological) myopia
Drusens are seen in Age related macular degeneration

questions.text: A child had following sign seen on fundoscopy. Which cannot be diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hunter disease does not have cherry red spot

questions.text: A 5 year old boy presents to clinic with unilateral vision loss and white reflex on retinoscopy. On retinal examination, there were retinal telangiectasia with hard exudates seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Coats disease is an idiopathic retinal telangiectasia that is generally of onset in early childhood. It is associated with intraretinal and subretinal exudation, and frequently exudative retinal detachment, without signs of vitreoretinal traction. A genetic predisposition may be involved as at least some patients have a somatic mutation in the NDP gene, which is also mutated in Norrie disease.

questions.text: The following was seen in a patient in both eyes. What should be done.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Grade 4 hypertensive retinopathy: more of soft exudates and flame hemaoorages goes in favour of hypertensive retinopathy
Malignant hypertension is an expression of accelerated progression of the hypertensive state in a patient with relatively young arteries, undefended by sclerosis. It is associated with renal insufficiency and the picture of the fundus is known as hypertensive neuroretinopathy, dominated by the appearance of oedema.

questions.text: What is the primary treatment of a patient with splashed tomato appearance in retina?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Central retinal vein occlusion
PRP is main management

choices.text: Outer retinal layers are mainly involved
Painless loss of vision with metamorphosia

questions.text: All are true for a patient with following observation except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Drusens in Age related macular degeneration in old age: the patient usually presents with distorted vision with painless central visual loss. Amsler's chart testing usually shows distortion of lines or scotoma. In dry ARMD, oral antioxidant is given.
Vit C, Vit E
Zinc, copper
Lutein, zeaxanthin

questions.text: White centered retinal hemorrhage are seen most commonly in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Roth Spots are defined as a white centered retinal hemorrhage and are associated with multiple systemic illnesses, most commonly bacterial endocarditis.
They may be observed in endocarditis, leukemia, diabetes, pernicious anemia, ischemic events, hypertensive retinopathy and rarely in HIV retinopathy.

questions.text: ‘a’ wave in electro-retinogram represents
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A negative a-wave, possibly representing the activity of the rods and cones
A positive (composite) b-wave arising in the inner retinal layers; and, with strong stimuli, a secondary rise in potential. It is due to bipolar/Muller cells
C-wave (generally not seen), related not to visual processes but to retinal metabolism, associated particularly with the pigmentary epithelium.

choices.text: Myelination of optic nerve starts here
Most common site of central retinal vein occlusion
Prominent in later stages of glaucoma

questions.text: Pic of optic nerve head is show. True for encircled portion are all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lamina cribrosa
Myelination of optic nerve is by oligodendrocytes, and stops at lamina

questions.text: What could be the most common ophthalmic manifestation of patient of Multiple sclerosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Multiple sclerosis. T1-weighted axial MR image showing characteristic periventricular plaques
Ophthalmic features
Common. Optic neuritis (usually retrobulbar)
Others: internuclear ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus.
Uncommon. Skew deviation, ocular motor nerve palsies, hemianopia

questions.text: Which is false
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A- Central field
B- Blind spot is due to optic disc
C- Peripheral field limit

questions.text: Temporal lobe lesions have which type of visual field deects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Posterior visual pathway lesions are congrous (symmetrical).

Retrochiasmal lesions are homonymous

Temporal lobe has superior defects

choices.text: Seen in right side optic tract

questions.text: True for the following visual field defects will be all of following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Left homonymous hemianopia

Left temporal loss and right nasal loss is there. Homonymous defects are seen in retrochiasmal lesions.

questions.text: In which of these, visual field defects will respect vertical meridian
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Optic tract lesion will have contralateral homonymous hemianopia

questions.text: Van Herrick method is used to assess
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A comparison of the depth of the peripheral anterior chamber to the peripheral corneal thickness is used to determine the degree of shallowness of the anterior chamber in the van Herrick method.

questions.text: Diffuse choroidal hemangioma is  seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased episcleral venous pressure is also seen in Sturge Weber

questions.text: A 75 year old lady with Giant cell arteritis will  have which likely ocular condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Arteritic ishemic optic neuropathy

The typical features of giant cell arteritis are constant headaches, which may be unilateral or bilateral, in the temporal area with prominent vessels which are tender. 
Features:
Headache
Scalp tenderness; palpable, tender, non-pulsatile temporal artery
Proximal muscle and joint, aches ‘polymyalgia rheumatica’
Anorexia, weight loss, fever
Jaw claudication
Cranial nerve palsies

questions.text: Wallenberg associated Horner syndrome involves which pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Central sympathetic pathway (A in the pic) affected in
• Brainstem disease – commonly stroke (e.g. lateral medullary infarction), but also tumour, demyelination
• Syringomyelia
• Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome

Preganglionic sympathetic pathway (B in the pic) affected in
• Pancoast tumour
• Thoracic spinal cord lesion
• Miscellaneous neck lesions (thyroid tumour, enlarged lymph nodes, trauma, postsurgical)

Postganglionic sympathetic pathway (C in the pic) affected in
• Internal carotid artery dissection
• Nasopharyngeal tumour
• Cavernous sinus mass

questions.text: Which is the most accurate tonometer
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The intraocular pressure within the eye normally varies from 10 to 21 mm Hg. Overall god standard is Goldmann tonometer

Tonopen is preferred tonometer in irregular corneal surfaces/corneal opacities/over bandage contact lenses.

questions.text: A hypermetropic patient with closed angles on gonioscopy has IOP of 25 mm Hg with normal optic disc and normal visual fields. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The optic disc is nomal with normal cup:disc ratio

choices.text: Asymmetry of the cup: disc ratio > 0.2 between the two eyes

questions.text: All are indicative of optic nerve head changes associated with glaucoma except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Roenne nasal step is visual field change
Optic nerve head changes associated with glaucoma are thought to be seen prior to the development of visual field loss.
Asymmetry of the cup: disc ratio > 0.2 between the two eyes is indicative of glaucoma

choices.text: Increased frequency of the topical steroid

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with acute anterior uveitis. The IOP is 50 mm Hg and the iris is bowed forward. Which of the following measures would be most effective?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This case describes iris bombé, which can occur if the aqueous humor produced by the ciliary
body is unable to move to anterior chamber. The iris is pushed forward
peripherally and causes a secondary angle closure.  A peripheral iridotomy is necessary to
create an alternate location for the aqueous.

questions.text: A 80 yr old patient with increased IOP and dandruff like material seen over lens and pupil margin with pigmented trabecular meshwork is likely to have
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pseudoexfoliative material is deposited in eyes
Its most common secondary glaucoma

questions.text: A new born child had this sign in cornea. The IOP also was high. What could be presenting clinical features?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Discrete corneal opacities appear as lines with a double contour (Haab striae, due to rupture of Descemet’s membrane in congenital glaucoma

choices.text: Patient should be in primary gaze
If corneal diameter is 12mm, value of B is 4 mm

questions.text: What is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A- marginal reflex distance 1
B- marginal reflex distance 2
upper eyelid covers 1/6th of cornea. Here it covers 2 mm
If corneal diameter is 12mm, value of A is 4 mm, B is 6 mm

Lower eyelid is at level of limbus
The reflex will be at center of cornea

questions.text: What eyelash sign here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Graying of eyelashes is poliosis

choices.text: 2 lakh IU oral Vit A at 1,4, 16 days
2 lakh IU oral Vit A at 0,1, 14 days
1 lakh IU oral Vit A at 1,4, 16 days
50000 IU oral Vit A at 0,1, 14 days

questions.text: 16 months old child of with the following condition is given
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: What is this device used for
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Measurement of proptosis with an exophthalmometer

questions.text: The following test done for?.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The phenol red thread test is a useful assessment of aqueous tear production.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of unilateral adult proptosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The most common cause of unilateral childhood proptosis is most often orbital cellulitis, secondary to ethmoid sinusitis or respiratory tract infections.

choices.text: Ptosis is worse at the end of the day
Antibodies against receptors in smooth muscle are present

questions.text: All of the following are true for this condition except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease in which antibodies mediate damage and destruction of acetylcholine receptors in striated muscle.
Ptosis is insidious, bilateral and frequently asymmetrical. Typically worse at the end of the day. Worse on prolonged (60 second) upgaze due to fatigue. Cold inhibits the breakdown of acetylcholine by acetylcholinesterase (ice pack test), improves ptosis.

questions.text: A syndrome which is a rare idiopathic condition caused by non-specific granulomatous inflammation of the cavernous sinus, superior orbital fissure and/or orbital apex. It is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tolosa–Hunt syndrome is a rare idiopathic condition caused by non-specific granulomatous inflammation of the cavernous sinus, superior orbital fissure and/or orbital apex. It is a diagnosis of exclusion and should be investigated fully.

questions.text: A patient eyeball protrudes  before and after straining/Valsalva. What is likely condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Primary orbital varices (combined venous–lymphatic malformations of the orbit - consist of a plexus of thinwalled distensible low-flow vein-like vessels that are commonly. They are
probably hamartomatous (hamartoma – a disorganized overgrowth of mature tissues normally present in the involved area).

questions.text: Most common benign tumour in orbit in adults is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cavernous hemangioma is retrobulbat benign tumour with cavernous spaces in histology

questions.text: A middle aged female with mild proptosis with optociliary shunts, tubular optic nerve enlargement is associated with which of following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Optic nerve sheath meningioma is a benign tumour arising from meningothelial cells of the arachnoid villi surrounding the intraorbital, or less commonly the intracanalicular, portion of the optic nerve.
psammomatous (A) histopathology is seen, CT shows thickening and calcification of the optic nerve (B)

C is Lisch nodules seen in NF1, associated with optic glioma

questions.text: Transmitted pulsatile proptosis is seen in all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Pulsatile proptosis seen in carotico-caverous fistula, fracture roof orbit, sphenoid dysplasia as in neurofibromatosis, menigiocele

questions.text: Associated finding with the condition are all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Blow out # leading to tear drop sign.
Forced duction and the differential intraocular pressure (IOP) test (increasing IOP as a restricted muscle presses on the globe) are positive.
Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia involving the lower lid, cheek, side of nose, upper lip, upper teeth and gums

questions.text: Which action is earliest affected in chronic stages of thyroid eye disease:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Most common muscle involved is inferior rectus, so the action mostly involved is elevation as IR fibrosis will not allow eye to go up.

questions.text: All of the following are done in management of a patient with thyroid eye disease except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Head elevation while sleep is done to decrease periorbital edema
Eyelid taping while sleep to prevent corneal exposure
Lubricants if case of cornea exposure
Steroids are mainstay of treatment
IOP control as IOP can be high due to increased episcleral venous pressure

questions.text: A patient has regurgitation from opposite puncta on syringing and no regurgitation on pressure over lacrimal sac. Most likely obstruction is in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Common canalicular block - there is no regurgitation on pressure over lacrimal sac
Regurgitation through opposite puncta on syringing.

choices.text: Recurrence suggestive of basal cell carcinoma

questions.text: All are true for the following lesion in a young girl with painless eyelid swelling except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A chalazion (meibomian cyst) is a sterile chronic granulomatous inflammatory lesion (lipogranuloma) of the meibomian gland
It more in upper eyelid as meibomian glands are more in upper eyelid
Its painless inner eyelid swelling
Histopathology shows a lipogranulomatous chronic inflammatory picture with extracellular fat deposits. A recurrent chalazion should be biopsied to exclude sebaceous cell carcinoma.
Infection of chaazion leads to internal hordeolum

choices.text: Vision becomes impaired due to induced astigmatism
Induces corneal steepening in the axis of the pterygium
Usually present on the nasal side
Encroaches upon the cornea destroying the superficial layers of the stroma and Bowman’s membrane.

questions.text: All of the statements are true for the condition in the image except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Induces astigmatism with the effect of corneal flattening in the axis of the pterygium

choices.text: Ethylene diamine tetra acetic acid chelation

questions.text: The treatment for progressive keratoconus is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

C3R is done with riboflavin under UV A rays to stop progression in keratoconus

questions.text: Which one is not seen in vernal kertoconjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
A- Shield ulcer
Correct Answer (D)

B- Horner tranta dots
C- Pseudogerontoxon
D- Herberts pits

questions.text: Which of the condition has amyloid deposition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Macular has mucopolysacchot=ride deposition

Granular has hyaline deposition

questions.text: Which investigation is used for Fuch corneal dystrophy  amongst the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fuch dystrophy  affects endothelium of cornea

Keratometry – for curvature of cornea
Placido disc examination- for corneal surface
Specular microscopy- for endothelium
Staining of the cornea with dye- to know about epithelial defect or punctate defects in dry eye

questions.text: The cataract seen in the condition with the following additional finding is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Wison disease has sunflower cataract and Kayser–Fleischer ring.

questions.text: This sign can be seen in all of the following conditions except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Granulomatous keratic precipitates  (KPs) may have a characteristic greasy , mutton fat appearance, without actually being granulomas themselves. Macrophages are responsible for the clinical appearance seen in granulomatous conditions in all except Juvenile idiopathic arthriti.

questions.text: Which ocular sign is seen in patient of Toxoplasmosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Headlight in fog appearance

questions.text: A male patient presents with recurrent oro-genital ulceration with Pathergy test positive. All can be true except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Behçet disease is an idiopathic, multisystem syndrome characterized by recurrent aphthous oral ulcers, genital ulceration and uveitis. It is not granulomatous. A transient mobile hypopyon in a relatively white eye is characteristic. Retinal vasculitis – arteritis as well as phlebitis, in contrast to pure venous involvement in sarcoidosis.

questions.text: What is the reason of pain in iridocyclitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Uvea is richly supplied with sensory nerves from the trigeminal nerve, irritation of which can which spasm of ciliary body leading to pain

questions.text: Most common manifestation of ocular sarcoidosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sarcoidosis is an example of panuveitis, but mostly it presents as granulomatous anterior uveitis

questions.text: What is the refractive error in the given pic
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: What is the refractive index of center of lens
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Refracting Medium Refractive Index
Air 1.000
Cornea 1.376
Aqueous humour 1.336
Lens (cortex-core) 1.386–1.406
Vitreous humour 1.336

questions.text: During refraction, the reflex in case of myopia of 1 D will move in which direction if done from distance of 2/3 m
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

If done at 2/3 m, the reflex will

Move in same direction in – hypermetrope, emmetrope and myopia of < 1> 1.5 D

choices.text: The cornea curvature of vertical axis might be more than horizontal
Horizontal axis steeper, against the rule
Vertical axis steeper, against the rule

questions.text: In keratometry, it was found that the vertical and horizontal axis of cornea have radius of curvature of 6.1 mm and 6.9 mm radius respectively. What is the interpretation among these?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Horizontal axis steeper is known as against the rule

Vertical axis steeper is known as with the rule

Smaller radius of curvature = more steep

More cornea curvature = more steep

questions.text: What is the refractive error at birth?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

At birth, the axial length of child is 16.5 mm (as compared to normal adult of 24 mm at around 14-16 years of age)

questions.text: Which prescription of glasses corresponds to point D
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

D is mixed astigmatism

A option satisfies mixed astigmatism with the rule

choices.text: It is a corneal procedure to remove spectacles
Myopia is corrected by central ablative flattening of cornea
It can be done for hypermetropes as well

questions.text: True for LASIK are all about?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

In LASIK (laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis), excimer laser beam ablates the corneal stroma after lifting a flap of the cornea with a microkeratome blade or femtosecond laser (femto-LASIK). The flap is then reposited.

questions.text: Which has Elevation, intorsion, adduction as actions
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A- Annulus of Zinn B- Superior oblique muscle C- Trochlea D- Superior rectus muscle

choices.text: The superior oblique arises from the apex of the orbit
It runs forwards to the trochlea, changes its direction and inserts posteriorly
Trochlea is anatomical origin of superior oblique
It is supplied by trochlear nerve

questions.text: All are true for superior oblique except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The superior oblique arises from the common origin at the apex of the orbit, runs forwards to the trochlea, a cartilaginous ring at the upper and inner angle of the orbit and, having threaded through this, becomes tendinous. The tendon changes its direction completely and runs over the globe under the superior rectus to attach itself above and lateral to the posterior pole.

Trochlea is functional origin of superior oblique

questions.text: Yoke muscle of Right superior oblique is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Yoke muscles follow herring law and works in both eyes at a time.

questions.text: Patient has no diplopia in which gaze
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Always see primary position- left eye has ptosis, down and out eye- classical of 3rd nerve palsy.

questions.text: In right SR palsy, patient will experience diplopia maximum in which direction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

He will have vertical diplopia on looking up and horizontal diplopia on looking right.

choices.text: In the direction of paralysed muscle
Opposite to direction of paralysed muscle

questions.text: In paralytic squints, patient will experience maximum diplopia in which direction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Comitant squints don’t have diplopia

questions.text: Which test cannot be used for measuring angle of deviation in a squint patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Titmus fly test is for stereopsis

choices.text: Right eye towards right, left eye towards left
Right eye towards left, left eye towards right

questions.text: In complete right LR palsy, where will be the eye is levoversion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

There is no diplopia also in levoversion

questions.text: What could be the answer if the patient is esophoria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The spot of light seen through the red cylinders appears as a long red line perpendicular to the
direction of the cylinders or grooves. If the cylinders are placed with their axes horizontal, the red line will be vertical. If there is orthophoria the bright spot will appear to be in the centre of the vertical red line.

Esodeviation have uncrossed diplopia
Exodeviation have crossed diplopia

questions.text: All are treatment modalities of amblyopia except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pin hole is a quick method to know refractive error

questions.text: Identify the test being done
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Prism bar- for assessment of strabismus (cover unvover with prisms)

Measures angle of deviation for near and distances in any positions of gaze.

The Maddox Wing measures the size of heterophorias (latent deviations) and small heterotropias (manifest deviations) at near

choices.text: Diplopia with limitation of medial or lateral gaze
Fracture involving at least 50% of orbital floor (within 2 weeks)

questions.text: A 20 yr old male patient was hit by a tennis ball to his left eye while playing lawn tennis, he was taken to ophthalmology dept in railway hospital for further examination and was found that there is Diplopia unable to feel the infra orbital region of left eye and left eye enophthalmos .what is the criteria for surgical repair in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

It’s condition of blowout fracture, it’s the most common fracture of orbit, size blunt object > size of orbital aperture, causes are fall, traffic accidents personal violence. 

Triad – enopthalmos diplopia and infraorbital fracture. Diagnosed by tear drop sign in D ray. Surgical repair is only done when fracture involving more than 50 % of orbital floor (within 2 weeks), enophthalmos > 2mm, Diplopia with limitation of upward or downward gaze.

questions.text: A surgical technique by which all intraocular contents are removed while preserving the remaining scleral shell, extraocular muscle attachments, and surrounding orbital adnexa is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Eviseration indications are:

Bleeding anterior staphyloma

Panophthalmitis

Expulsive suprachoroid hemorrage

Severe injured eye

choices.text: Alkali are more dangerous than acis
Lime is a common alkali to cause injury
It leads to severe dry eyes due to disruption of limbal stem cells
Checking severity of dry eyes with Schirmer test is 1st thing to be done

questions.text: All are true for chemical injuries to eye except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Alkalis are more dangerous as they tend to penetrate more deeply into eye.

Acids coagulate surface proteins, forming a protective barrier the

The most common alkali is lime, others are ammonia, sodium hydroxide

Ammonia produce severe damage because of rapid penetration.

questions.text: Which of the following will not cause floaters?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Floaters are mostly caused due to involvement of vitreous

questions.text: A 65 years old man with history of a recent bronchitis awoke this morning with a red eye and has no other symptoms. He has no signiﬁcant medical problems. On examination, the patient has a sector of the eye that is diffusely red without congestion of the conjunctival vessels. There was no pain or decreased vision. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

A subconjunctival hemorrhage is in the potential space between the conjunctiva and sclera. • The conjunctival and deeper vessels are not congested or inﬂamed as in conjunctivitis or scleritis. • Scleritis can appear in a sector pattern, but is usually associated with pain or tenderness. • A pterygium forms due to chronic UV exposure and presents over years, not overnight.

questions.text: A patient sustained blunt trauma to the eye 6 months ago and now presents with blurring of vision and glare. What is the most likely condition
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Of these, iridodialysis can cause blurred vision and glare

questions.text: 34-year-old male working as a welder, came with complaint of pain, redness & watery eyes. The following image was seen on slit lamp. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Foreign body like this should be removed

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about blindness according to recent NPCB

1. Inability of a person to count fingers from a distance of 3m

2. vision less than 6/60 with the best available spectacle correction

3. diminution of field vision to 50 degrees in better eye
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Blindness defined according to revised NPCB and visual impairment criteria is - 

1. Inability of a person to count fingers from a distance of 3m 

2. Vision 3/60 or less with available spectacle correction 

3. Diminution of field vision to 10 degree or less in better eye
